texts.textentryhtml:
The selection of objects used in a tea gathering reflect the host’s aesthetic vision. The practice of Japanese tea, cha no yu (literally The Aguilar sisters of the Kewa Pueblo had maintained a steady business selling their pottery to visitors stopping in the pueblo from the Santa Fe
train. However, as the market for pottery in the pueblo became saturated and their sales declined, the sisters sought the advice of local pottery dealer Julius Seligman, who encouraged them to reinvigorate their business by creating ceramic vessels for the art and tourist market rather than for use by other Kewa community members. The Aguilar sisters continued to hand-construct a range of jars and bowls for storage and food as well as the popular tinajas, or water jars. After building their clay vessels primarily with the coil method, the artists fired the pottery in open kilns fueled by cottonwood bark. On Seligman’s advice, the sisters adorned their vessels in bold geometric patterns, often rendered in striking red, orange, or black pigment over a cream-colored slip, to catch the attention of potential buyers.

Richard M. Howard, Santa Fe (NM) [1]. Purchased by Rick Dillingham, Santa Fe (NM), 1970s [2]. Unknown private collection, by 2024; [Adobe Gallery, Santa Fe (NM), 2024]; purchased by the Princeton University Art Museum, 2024.  [1] According to Adobe Gallery. [2] According to Adobe Gallery.
